items.title: Christmas market vendors, organizers say ‘too many markets’ are hurting business
items.summary_auto: Beverly Glover has been selling fruitcakes and other confections at holiday markets across Calgary for eight years. Now, she's feeling the effects of a seemingly oversaturated market.

items.title: A sacred pipe returns to Whitecap Dakota First Nation after 135 years
items.summary_auto: More Indigenous communities across Canada are reuniting with items that were taken or given away generations ago. The Vatican and the Canadian Catholic Church are reportedly working on an agreement to return about 100,000 Indigenous items Catholic missions sent to Rome in the 1920s.

items.title: Vatican returns Indigenous cultural items to Canada's Catholic bishops on a 'historic day'
items.summary_auto: A century-old Inuvialuit kayak once used for beluga and whale hunts, and 61 other cultural objects from First Nations, Métis and Inuit communities long held in Vatican Museums vaults, will return to Canada on Dec. 6 after Pope Leo on Saturday gifted the items to a delegation of Catholic bishops.

items.title: Is Mark Carney's budget a Progressive Conservative budget?
items.summary_auto: Attempting perhaps to turn a story about his own leadership into a story about whether the media have unfairly focused on Conservative dissent, Pierre Poilievre challenged reporters to pay as much attention to criticism levelled against the federal budget by Liberal MP Nathaniel Erskine-Smith.

items.title: It’s been a couple of rough weeks for Donald Trump. Is even worse to come for the U.S. president?
items.summary_auto: This could have been a good week for Donald Trump, in which the U.S. president could have chalked up a political win over the Democrats with the end of the government shutdown. But any gloating time was short-lived, overshadowed by the spectre of Jeffrey Epstein and Trump’s past connection to the late convicted sex offender.

items.title: How 4 different expansions are planned for Canada's largest oil export pipeline system
items.summary_auto: Enbridge is pursuing several expansions to export oil through its pipeline system, which should meet the needs of the oil industry. So what does that mean for Alberta Premier Danielle Smith's lobbying for a new pipeline?

items.title: Carney heads to the UAE amid questions about atrocities in Sudan
items.summary_auto: Prime Minister Mark Carney will travel to the United Arab Emirates next week, as both that country and Canada face questions over alleged links to actrocities in Sudan.

items.title: Dad was a Grey Cup champion. I want to hate what the sport did to him but it's not that simple
items.summary_auto: Gary Chown was a two-time Grey Cup champion with the Montreal Alouettes. While mourning his loss, his daughter Hayley Chown has been coming to terms with the sacrifices he made to the sport and her complicated feelings about football.

items.title: Toronto mansion owners ordered to tear down wall on their property, only a year after city approved it
items.summary_auto: The owners of a mansion in Toronto's Rosedale neighbourhood are being ordered to tear down a wall built around part of their property — only a year after the city allowed them to build it.

items.title: U.S. appeals court upholds hate crime convictions over 2020 killing of Ahmaud Arbery
items.summary_auto: A U.S. federal appeals court on Friday upheld the hate crime convictions of three white men who chased Ahmaud Arbery, a Black jogger, through their Georgia subdivision with pickup trucks before one of them killed him with a shotgun in February 2020.

items.title: Weekend transit shutdown cancelled in Montreal as union, STM reach tentative deal
items.summary_auto: The public transit strike which would have shut down bus and Metro service in Montreal for the weekend has been cancelled after a last-minute tentative deal was reached Friday night.

items.title: Alberta premier says loss of measles elimination status concerning, urges vigilance
items.summary_auto: Alberta Premier Danielle Smith says Canada recently losing its measles elimination status is concerning, but her government might not have many other options on the table to help get it back.

items.title: Trump cuts tariffs on beef, coffee and other foods, as U.S. inflation concerns mount
‘I shouldn’t be spending this much money on food’
items.summary_auto: How did fast food go from budget-friendly to overly expensive? CBC’s Jenna Benchetrit explains.

items.title: Iran’s 'water bankruptcy problem' is nothing new, says UN expert
items.summary_auto: The country of more than 90 million is facing an unprecedented water and energy crisis as reservoirs shrink to record lows, endangering drinking water and power supplies.

items.title: Residents of this Ontario neighbourhood were hit with $14K per household for work done a decade ago
Bob Rae, on his last day at the UN, says: ‘I think I helped make a difference’
items.summary_auto: On his very last day as Canada's ambassador to the United Nations, Bob Rae spoke to As It Happens host Nil Kӧksal.

items.title: Paulatuk, N.W.T., wants to fix drafty homes as part of its net-zero goal
items.summary_auto: The Paulatuk Energy Working Group has a goal of becoming carbon neutral. But everyone – from residents to those leading the project – agree making sure homes don’t waste that energy is a critical part of the target.

items.title: Man found guilty of murder in stabbing death of Misha Pavelick at Sask. grad party in 2006
items.summary_auto: A man has been found guilty of second-degree murder in the death of Misha Pavelick, 19, who was fatally stabbed during a graduation party at a campground.

items.title: Spacecraft designed to study the effect of solar storms delayed by a solar storm
items.summary_auto: Bob’s Blog: NASA’s latest mission, designed to study the effects of the solar wind on the atmosphere of Mars, was ironically delayed on the launch pad due to a solar storm affecting conditions here on Earth.
